channel.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
channel.description:
Up until a few weeks ago, I had Windows 7 Ultimate x86 installed as a dual boot on my computer, until WGA fucked me over, so when i went to make a fresh install of it again, I decided to give x64 a shot. It's been working pretty smoothly up until this week; startup is very slow, randomly freezes when performing not-very memory intensive tasks (mIRC, Chrome, etc), etc.
I've checked the event viewer and it reports nothing related to those freezes, my only guess at the moment is that some application might have corrupted some of my registry entries, so I'm going to clean it and see if the problem gets better. If it doesn't, I guess I'll just switch back to 32-bit.
Just to add, the registry corruption (if even existent) is most likely due to my laptop overheating and unexpectedly shutting down. Although this, too, happened in the 32-bit installation and caused no problems whatsoever.
Anyone else have an idea?

item.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

Ok well now, my final assumption is that it was due to the excessive overheating. Therefore, I took the time today to completely dissemble my laptop and clean all the dust in the fan (it was plagued), and I’ve been running it for about an hour with no problem (whereas before it would crash after about 10-15 min).

Also, I’m using SpeedFan to monitor temperatures. It hasn’t exceeded 53°C so far.

edit: Yeah, seems to be it was the overheating. Even though my laptop is now fairly cool, I preferred to err on the side of caution and ordered a USB-connected Belkin Laptop-Cooler, which I’ve heard great things about (seems to be it reduces temperature by like 15°C) and seems to have good reviews.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

ok the problem is still occurring

i’ve concluded that it’s due to a faulty motherboard since windows xp randomly BSODs now when it used to never happen, ubuntu randomly spits out an irreparable error that forces me to restart and the bios sometimes doesn’t even boot

item.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:13, topic:335530”][quote author=c|p link=topic=431910.msg3170501#msg3170501 date=1270404644]
The driver for my Creative X-Fi XtremeGamer card (it’s shit, don’t remind me), has some lame ‘3D Audio Enhancement’ feature, enabled by default. Creative is notorious for their shitty drivers, and this particular feature causes huge memory leaks (audiodg.exe using all available RAM in excess, hundreds of hard faults/second, very high CPU usage), wouldn’t necessarily cause slow startup, but you get the idea.
[/quote]Not only that but the “3D Audio Enhancement” makes it sound fukken worse. All these “fancy” audio junk they provide just ruins the fucking sound and makes it sound more digital and less authentic. Creative are fucking faggots[/quote]
maybe, but i have some creative speakers and they sound brilliant.

item.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

Ok, well I reinstalled x86 and the freezes were still occurring, just like in x64, even though 32-bit worked flawlessly before. As weird as it may sound, turns out it was my fucked up laptop battery which caused the problem. My BIOS would also randomly freeze when starting up occasionally. I took out the battery and am currently running on an AC adapter until I get a new battery.

Turns out it wasn’t 64-bit causing the problem after all…

Read full topic

item.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

eczema3:

AFAIK, all Windows OS’ have failed @ x64 architectures.[/quote][quote=“Unhandled, post:3, topic:335530”]In my personal experience, I have found all x64 products made by microsoft to be infallibly complete and utter shit.

I pretty much agree with the above two statements. Both of my brothers have had nothing but problems from 7 Ultimate x64.

That being said, I do have 7 Ultimate x64 installed, but I have only used it to play Dragon Age: Origins. I basically installed the OS, installed firefox, tracked down hard to fine vista x64 drivers, install DA: Origins, played it for about 30 hours, and haven’t booted into it since. So I honestly have no idea how it would work as an every day OS. But I have been using amd64 linux for over 4 years, and it works great.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:5, topic:335530”]That is not going to fix any problems, your registry is perfectly fine. None of those minor issues should inhibit normal operation of your OS in the slightest.[/quote]That’s exactly what I thought although that’s the only potential cause that I can come up with since it was functioning relatively fine before this week.

I’ll also be performing a disk defragmentation in the near future to see if that speeds things up a bit.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

From my experience, Windows 7 Ultimate x86-64 runs better than Windows 7 RC1 x86 did for me (fresh install, not upgrade/whatever). Yes, they did make a lot of improvements between RC1 and release, but my point is x86-64 is fine.

Lots of drivers for Windows 7 (not just x86-64) are buggy as fuck.
The driver for my Creative X-Fi XtremeGamer card (it’s shit, don’t remind me), has some lame ‘3D Audio Enhancement’ feature, enabled by default. Creative is notorious for their shitty drivers, and this particular feature causes huge memory leaks (audiodg.exe using all available RAM in excess, hundreds of hard faults/second, very high CPU usage), wouldn’t necessarily cause slow startup, but you get the idea.

So, acknowledging the possibility of a similar issue, I would open up Resource Monitor (Task Manager -> Performance -> Resource Monitor) and keep it visible, then just use your computer as usual. When you lag hard just check out the CPU tab, Memory tab (Hard Faults/sec specifically), maybe keep an eye on Disk I/O too.

A side note, use CCleaner, it works well and uses the same registry cleaning techniques (not the only thing it does though).

Read full topic

item.title: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

That is not going to fix any problems, your registry is perfectly fine. None of those minor issues should inhibit normal operation of your OS in the slightest.

Read full topic
